p: HIV surveillance and programming targeting gay and bisexual men, other men who have sex with men and transgender women (MSM/TG) have until recently been neglected in countries with generalised HIV epidemics[ 1]. Over the last ten years, this has begun to change, with increasing funder and policymaker attention paid to the burden of HIV experienced by these populations[ 2– 4], including in South Africa’s National Strategic Plan for HIV, TB and STI’s[ 5]. Over this same period, coverage of antiretroviral treatment (ART) in sub-Saharan Africa has greatly expanded and AIDS-related mortality in general populations has fallen dramatically[ 6, 7]. Effective treatment to achieve viral suppression also avoids sexual transmission of the virus, including among MSM[ 8], and at the population level, ‘Treatment as Prevention’ (TasP) has the potential to reduce HIV incidence[ 9, 10]. Accordingly, UNAIDS set ‘care cascade’ targets specifying that of all HIV-positive individuals in a given population, 90% should be aware of their status, 90% of those aware should be on antiretroviral treatment (ART) and 90% of those on ART should be virally suppressed by 2020[ 11].
